transcripts.text: I just want to talk more about one of tonight's main stories, which is something that started here on LBC on Monday morning on Nick Ferrari's breakfast show.  Dr David Nicol speaking to Jacob Rees-Mogg.
Good morning, David.

My name's Dr David Nicol.  I'm a consultant neurologist.  I was actually involved in Yellowhammer and drafting the plans of mitigation for a new Brexit in March.  And my question to you, really, having been involved in writing plans of mitigation, having whistleblown because I felt they were unsafe, is what level of mortality rate are you willing to accept in the light of a no-deal Brexit?

Well, I don't think that there's any reason to suppose that a no-deal Brexit should lead to a mortality rate.  I think this is the worst excessive project fear, and I'm surprised that a doctor in your position would be fear-mongering in this way on public radio.
Can I remind you, I wrote the plans in mitigation.  In mitigation?

Well, you didn't write very good plans.  If you hadn't worked out how to mitigate, had you?  It's fortunate they're being written by other people now who are serious about mitigating rather than Ramona's.

Well, except to stop you there on the Sunday Times yesterday, the Royal Colleges who were involved in contact with the Department of Health have not yet been approached to update these documents.  Let me just get involved for a moment.  That's incorrect.

Doctor, doctor, and obviously I take you on face value because you say you're a doctor and I have to take that value.  Just to remind my listeners, Operation Yellowhammer is the plan that's implemented in the event of a no-deal Brexit.  How many people do you think, then, what is the mortality rate that you're working towards and why?
We don't know that.  That's not part of Yellowhammer.  And I remind you that Michael Gove said that this was the worst-case scenario.  That's incorrect.  Yellowhammer is not the worst-case scenario.
Sorry, pardon me, but as a general, why are people going to die?

because of all sorts of problems in terms of issues of access to drugs, the issue about radioisotopes, that have already been highlighted.  And when you get people at the Royal College saying they're very worried...

But again, as a journalist, I have to say, we've heard the health secretary, we've even heard the chairman of the British Pharmaceutical Association saying, if needs be, and this is extraordinary, they will fly drugs in.  You seem to be...
That's right, that's correct.

There are reserved... plans to fly drugs in if necessary.  This is a major focus of government policy.  I think it's deeply responsible, Dr Nicol, of you to call in and try and spread fear across the country.  I think it's typical of Remainer campaigners and you should be quite ashamed, I'm afraid.
I must allow you a quick response.
Which is why I contacted the GMC.  So I'm quite happy.  if you want to refer me to the GMC, we can talk about it there.

Jacob Rees-Mogg accusing Dr David Nicol of being deeply irresponsible.  On Tuesday, Dr Philip Lee resigned from the Conservative Party, joining the Lib Dems.  And on this programme, he cited that exchange as part of the reason.

The person who should be ashamed of that interview is Jacob Rees-Mogg.  You know, you can say it with a posh voice.  But if it's BS, it's BS, OK?  And I cannot believe that he thinks that's an appropriate way to speak to a professional person who actually, along with General Medical Council Code, which I have to follow as a doctor, probity about putting patients first before yourself, and for him to have taken him out in that sort of shock jock alternative right way, I'm sorry, it was disgraceful, and Mr Rees-Mogg should apologise.

In the House of Commons today, where he's protected by parliamentary privilege, Jacob Rees-Mogg compared Dr Nicol to the discredited anti-vaccine campaigner, a man who was struck off the medical register, Andrew Wakefield.
A lot of Remainers wish to make our skins crawl, and I am afraid it seems to me that Dr David Nicol is as irresponsible as Dr Wakefield.
What he had to say—I will repeat it—is as irresponsible as Dr Wakefield in threatening in threatening that people will die because we leave the European Union?
What level of irresponsibility was that?

Jacob Rees-Mogg again accusing Dr David Nicol of irresponsibility and making that comparison in the House of Commons with Andrew Wakefield.  Well, in the last hour on this programme, we got first reaction from Dr Nicol.  He'd been tweeting a little this afternoon, but as you heard, you may have heard live here a moment or two ago, he hadn't actually heard the Jacob Rees-Mogg clip until we played it to him, and this was what he told me.
I mean, this is an attempt by a government minister to bully a whistleblower, which is outrageous, OK?  And I challenge him to repeat that outside the House of Commons, and if he does, I'll sue him.
As far as you're concerned, he's defamed you?

Yes.  And actually, this comes to the core.  Forget Brexit for a minute.  This is the willingness of a government minister to pay attention to expert advice.  Now, you may disagree with those expert advice, but, you know, you shouldn't attempt to bully the whistleblower by using parliamentary privilege to get away with it.  It's an act of a coward.
And to be clear, you did not say people would die in your conversation with him.  You asked him what level of mortality rate he would accept.

Yes.  And I still would ask that question.  When people say that there's bumps in the road, that question should be asked to every person that holds the same view as Jacob Rees-Mogg, is how many bumps there are, how big they are, how are you going to mitigate against them, and what level of harm, and obviously as a doctor I'm concerned about patient harm, there will be.  Because the answer is not zero.  I don't know what the answer is, but it definitely is not zero.  And every, you know, the BMA, Royal Colleges, all have warned about the risk of no deal.  I'm extremely grateful for the support I've received, literally on the train from very senior members of the British Medical Association as I head towards College Green.
Because you're going to College Green to do lots of interviews, I imagine, but what else are you going to do?

I want to call them out.  I think I am literally going to shout at the House of Commons and say, if you actually, you know, this is, you know, forget medicine, forget Brexit for a minute.  This cuts the core of whether a government is willing to accept, whether to listen to the views of an expert, yes or no.  You may disagree with that view.  If you disagree with that view, you should say so, but she's not the same expert.
Do you think you've got under his skin?

Frankly, that's irrelevant.  What I'm interested in is the evidence.  There's been a lack of scrutiny of the evidence, which is why I'm just repeating what I've said.  When, you know, spectators say there'll be a few bumps on the road, they need to define what that bump is.  Now, as a doctor, I define a bump as well as my patient will be harmed or not.

It might be useful.  I didn't realise you hadn't heard the clip until literally just now.  Literally that second, yes.  It might be useful just to hear it again, just to let some of the words and the tone sink in.
I'd rather not.  I actually want to get down to College Green, and if Steve Bray is there, I want to borrow his megaphone.
This is Steve Bray, famous for his megaphone and trying to stop Brexit.  You're going to use the megaphone to try and shout at Jacob Rees-Mogg?

Yes, because I think I need to call them out.  You know, the best way to treat a bully is to show them that you will not be bullied.  But, you know, this man is, you know, this is an attack not just on me, but on every expert who's contributed to Yellowhammer.  And I would encourage any expert who is aware that they've got evidence that there's a risk to the citizens of this country, I would suggest they speak to either Deb Cohn at Newsnight I don't know you that well, but Rosalind Irwin at Sunday Times.  Really, I think you're a fantastic investigative journalist.  Those are the people I've shared the files with.  Obviously, a very limited number of doctors have seen them.  No one has disagreed with my clinical opinion.  I've said to him before, if he's got a problem with my probity, he can refer me to the GMC.  That's where Andrew Wakefield went and was struck off.  I'm particularly offended by the association with Andrew Wakefield.  When I've been very clear about my views and support of MMR, even since my own daughter was born, I was not an observer about that.  And just this week she was doorstepped by the Mail Online.  So, you know, I'm not going to take any crap, frankly, from Jacob Rees-Mogg.
Do you think he will repeat what he said outside Parliament?
No, because he's a coward.

Dr David Nicholls speaking, giving his first reaction on this programme just after five o'clock.  He's now on College Green.  He made it.  Darren has called in.  A lot of people want to talk about this, as you can imagine.  Darren is in Stevenage.  What's your take on this, Darren?

Oh, my God, Eddie.  Theresa May, when she referred to the Conservative Party as the nasty party, I think the nasty party's back.  I was a Conservative councillor for 20 years, and I'm finished with the party now.
Because of this?
Yeah.

This is the straw that's broke the camel's back.  Hearing that again today, and I owe my life to a consultant because back in Easter, I was diagnosed with kidney cancer.  and had to have my kidney removed back in June.  So, and for Jacob Rees-Mogg to say that to a consultant, about a consultant, is disgusting.
Thank you, Darren.  Jeremy is in Haringey.  Hi, Jeremy.

Oh, hi, Eddie.  Thanks for taking my call.  Yeah, I was just horrified by what Reece Mogg said in the comments.  I've been absolutely disgusted by the attitude.  It's so high handed.  It's awful.  But the point I wanted to make.  which I don't know whether it's accurate or not, is that the Yellowhammer report was itself commissioned by government as part of its risk assessment.  So it's not as if this doctor was, as it were, a maverick going about spreading fear on his own account.  He was actually commissioned, obviously, by government to contribute to the risk assessment.  So it wasn't a gratuitous... opinion of his.  It was something that the government itself commissioned him to assist in.  It's now been thrown back in his face as if he went out on a limb by himself and in order to undermine government policy.

And as we said in the interview, Jeremy, as we said in the interview, he did not say in that conversation, I think people will die.  He was asking Jacob Rees-Mogg what level of mortality rate he would find acceptable, which is a different thing.

If Rees-Mogg then turns the whole table on him and is portraying him as being an individual doctor, as it were, making his own independent trouble for governments, when in fact it wasn't.  He was brought in by government to assist in their own operation.
Jeremy, thank you for that.  Obviously, Jacob Rees-Mogg, very welcome on the programme anytime you want.  We'd like to have this conversation.
